conclusion: The work done by the gas during a cyclic process in a p-V diagram is equal to the area enclosed by the cycle.
In this case, the cycle is a triangle ABC.
The vertices are A, B, and C with coordinates $(V_A, p_A)$, $(V_B, p_B)$, and $(V_C, p_C)$ respectively.

premise: Volumes in liters: $V_A = 2$ L, $V_B = 2$ L, $V_C = 5$ L.
conclusion: Convert volumes to cubic meters: $V_A = 2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3$, $V_B = 2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3$, $V_C = 5 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3$.
The work done is the area of the triangle ABC.

premise: Base is the segment CA. Line segment CA is horizontal at pressure $p = 1 \times 10^5$ Pa.
conclusion: Length of base CA is $|V_C - V_A| = |5 \times 10^{-3} - 2 \times 10^{-3}| = 3 \times 10^{-3}$ m$^3$.

premise: Height is the perpendicular distance from point B to line segment CA. Pressure at point B is $p_B = 4 \times 10^5$ Pa.
Base of triangle is $3 \times 10^{-3}$ m$^3$ and height is $3 \times 10^5$ Pa.
conclusion: Area of the triangle is $\frac{1}{2} \times (3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3) \times (3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}) = 450$ J.

premise: Cycle is traversed in the clockwise direction (A→B→C→A).
conclusion: Net work done by the gas is positive.
